en: Interview with Karen Hughes, professor with the Ecology and Evolutionary Biology department of UT. Hughes discusses the impact that the fire had upon the fungi of the region and how the various species are recovering. She also elaborates on the role that fungi play in the forest, both in terms of nutrients in the soil and interacting with other organisms. This is a representative quote from the interview: "If you let some small fires burn out then the big ones don't get going, but we had a lot of fuel down in the Smokey's and we still do."

Interview with Karen Hughes, 2019-11-07 -- Great Smoky Mountains National Park
How long have you lived in East Tennessee?
Can you tell us about your career path coming here?
What can studying fungi tell us about the larger ecosystem?
Have you noticed a shift in diversity or populations over the course of your study?
By studying fungi, you can see the patterns over time in the Smokies?
Can you tell us about the days leading up to the fires?
What prompted the studies in the park?
What was the main focus of studying fungi after the fire?
What was your methodology like, what did the field research look like?
Why did new species of fungi begin to appear after the fire?
You mentioned that prior to the park's founding, there were more burns?
Is there anything surprising to come out of your research?
What made the immediate symbiosis between pine trees and fungus surprising?
What are some of the impacts of your research on the understanding of your discipline?
Is the change brought about by climate change on the Smokies an area you expect to research?
Is there anything about the wider context of your research you would like to share? Is there anything you would like to share with the public?

seo.title: Interview with Karen Hughes, 2019-11-07 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
